Geography: Main production areas: Sichuan, Yunnan, Guizhou.
Recently cultivated/propagated in: Shaanxi, Hubei, Hunan.
Maladies Treated: Low back and knee pain due to dampness (濕腰膝疼痛).
Leg flaccidity with tendon spasms (腳痿筋攣).
Blood strangury (xue lin) and hematuria (血淋，尿血).

Abdominal/pelvic masses (症瘕): fibroids of the uterus, ovarian cysts, endometriosis, pelvic inflammatory mass, menstrual blood retention due to gynatresia (陰道閉鎖的月經瀦留), old/existing extra-uterine (ectopic) pregnancy, teratoma of the internal genital organs, or certain gynecologic malignancies presenting as pelvic masses with distension pain or uterine bleeding.
Medical Function: Effects on the uterus (relaxant/contractile actions; observed in animals).
Effects on metabolism and anabolic activity.
Hepatoprotective support in heliotrine-induced hepatitis (observed in animals).
Dosage: Decoction: 6–10 g. May also be used in pills or powder form. Can be soaked in alcohol for drinking.
Samples of Formulae:
Name: xie qing tang with adjustment (加減瀉青丸). Source notes: listed as 小兒藥證直訣; excerpted in 《雜病証治新義》.
Application: Hypertension with headache, qi excess with constipation; pulse stringy, stiff and large at the three positions.
Composition (water decoction): Fang Feng (Saposhnikovia root) [防風], Long Dan Cao (Chinese Gentian root) [龍膽草], Shan Zhi Zi (Gardenia fruit) [山梔子], Da Huang (Rhubarb root/rhizome) [大黃], Huang Qin (Baikal skullcap root) [黃芩], Chuan Niu Xi (Cyathula root) [川牛膝].
Contraindications: Contraindicated during pregnancy, in cases of excessive menstrual bleeding, and in spermatorrhea.
Research:
Uterine effects: Extract of the herb relaxed the pregnant and non-pregnant uteri of guinea pigs and the non-pregnant uterus of cats, and caused contraction of the pregnant and non-pregnant uteri of rabbits and the pregnant uterus of cats [1,2].

Anti-fertility/anti-implantation: Benzene extract 2.5 g (raw herb)/kg administered by gavage to mice for 3 consecutive days starting on day 7 of pregnancy achieved 100% anti-pregnancy effectiveness (15 mice), with embryos expelled, death, or vaginal bleeding [3]. Additional report: benzene extract 250 mg/kg achieved 100% anti-fertility effectiveness; 500 mg/kg achieved 100% anti-implantation effectiveness; the ethyl acetate extract was less effective, and the alcohol extract was the weakest [4].

Hemorheology and anticoagulation: Decoction 10 g/kg by gavage, twice daily for 3 days, showed no significant effect on multiple hemorheologic indices in normal rats and in an acute blood stasis rat model. In anticoagulation testing, it significantly prolonged rat plasma recalcification time, indicating some blood-activating (anticoagulative) action, though weaker than Huai Niu Xi (懷牛膝) [5].

Metabolic/anabolic effects: Ecdysterone administered to young mice for 60 days markedly promoted body weight gain and increased hepatic and renal protein synthesis; hepatocytes showed proliferative activation with giant nuclei, binuclear or multinuclear cells. These effects were weaker in mature mice [6]. In rats, orally administered ecdysterone exerted anabolic effects: increased levator ani muscle weight in immature castrated male rats; in immature and mature rats it increased body weight, viscera and skeletal muscle weights, and total protein. It significantly affected carbohydrate metabolism by increasing hepatic and muscle glycogen, with minimal impact on fat metabolism [7]. Other reports found no androgen-like effects in castrated animals [8].

Choleretic: Ecdysterone 5 mg/(kg/day) by gavage, single dose or daily for 7 days, increased bile secretion in rats and altered bile composition by increasing bile acids and bilirubin and decreasing cholesterol [9].

Lipid-lowering/anti-atherosclerotic: Ecdysterone 10 mg/kg by gavage inhibited WR-1339–induced hypercholesterolemia and hypertriglyceridemia in rats, and suppressed experimental atherosclerosis in rabbits [10].

Immune modulation and cell effects: Ecdysterone 1 mg/kg intraperitoneally increased antibody-forming spleen cells in mice immunized with sheep red blood cells. It promoted protein synthesis in cultured human skin fibroblasts, while generally inhibiting DNA synthesis of cultured human lymphocytes stimulated by phytohemagglutinin [11].

Hepatoprotection: Ecdysterone accelerated normalization of liver function in rats with heliotrine-induced hepatitis [9].

1.
對子宮的作用： 
本品的流浸膏能使豚鼠已孕及未孕子宮和貓的未孕子宮弛緩，
使家兔 已孕及未孕子宮和貓的已孕子宮收縮[1,2]。
2.
抗生育作用： 
川牛膝的苯提取物2.5g(生 藥)/kg，從小白鼠妊娠第7日 開始，連續灌服3日
          。抗生育的有效率為100%(15只)， 使胚胎排出，死亡或陰道流血[3]。又報道，本品苯提取物250mg/kg抗 生育有效率為100%，500mg/kg抗 著床的有效率也為100%，而乙酸乙酯提取物效果較差，醇提取物作用最弱[4]。
3.
對血液流變學的影響： 
川牛膝煎劑l0g/kg灌 胃，每日2次，連續3日，對正 常及急性血淤模型大鼠的各項血液流變學指標均無明顯影響。在抗凝實驗中，對大鼠血漿復鈣時間明顯延長，表明本品有一定活血作用，但其效果 不如懷牛膝[5]。
4.
對代謝的影響： 
給幼鼠連續投與蛻皮甾酮60日 ，除明顯促進體重增加及肝腎蛋白合成增加外，尚可發現肝細胞處於分裂活化狀態，生成巨核，雙核或多核細胞。這些作用在成熟小鼠表現較弱[6]。 大鼠灌服蛻皮甾酮有同化作用，能增加未成熟閹割雄大鼠提肛肌重量，對未成熟及成熟大鼠可增加體重，內臟及骨骼肌重量和總蛋白量，對糖代謝 也有明顯影響，使肝糖原及肌糖原含量增加，但對脂肪代謝影響很小[7]。也有報道認 為本品對閹割動物無雄激素樣作用[8]。
5.
利膽作用： 
蛻皮甾酮5mg/(kg/d)灌 胃1次或連用7日，均能促進大 鼠膽汁分泌，並能改變膽汁的成分，使膽酸及膽紅素含量增加，膽固醇含量降低[9]。
6.
降脂作用： 
蛻皮甾酮10mg/kg灌 胃能抑制WR-1339所致大鼠高膽固醇血症及高甘油三酷血症，對兔實驗性動脈硬化 也有抑制作用[10]。
7.
對免疫功能的影響： 
蛻皮甾酮1mg/kg腹 腔注射，能使羊紅細胞免疫小鼠的脾臟抗體形成細胞增加。此外，能促進培養人皮膚成纖維細胞的蛋白質合成，但通常抑制植物血凝素刺激的培養 人淋巴細胞的DNA合成[11]。
8.
其他作用： 
蛻皮甾酮對天芥菜鹼(heliotrine)所 致肝炎大鼠，有加速肝功能恢復正常的作用[9]。

Research:
Cardio-vascular effect: When injected into the lower limbs of toads, water extract of su mu mildly constricted blood vessels; subsequent use of sodium nitrite could not dilate them. In vitro, an appropriate amount of aqueous solution of su mu increased the strength of contraction of frog hearts (animal experiments on toads and frogs).

Effect on central nervous system inhibition: Appropriate amounts of aqueous solution of su mu, delivered by various methods, promoted sleep in mice, rabbits, and guinea pigs. Large amounts caused anesthesia effects and even death. It inhibited the stimulating effects of strychnine or cocaine, but not the stimulating effect of morphine (animal experiments on mice, rabbits, and guinea pigs).

Antibacterial effects: A 10% decoction of su mu exhibited a strong bactericidal effect on Staphylococcus spp. and typhoid bacillus. It was effective against both Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacilli.

Transplanted heart study: Results announced by Heilongjiang Traditional Chinese Medical School showed that su mu distinctly prolonged the lifespan of transplanted hearts. The pathological morphology and ultrastructural changes of myocardial cells were markedly milder than in the model control group and closer to those of the Cyclosporin A group. Further observations via molecular biology and immunology indicated that su mu inhibited gene expression of perforin and granzyme B released by cytotoxic T cells, reducing host rejection reactions and thereby protecting the transplanted heart.

Wood: Brasilin 2%, which is easily oxidized in air to brasilein (responsible for the red color of su mu)
Volatile oil: major components d-α-phellandrene and ocimene (responsible for the fragrance of su mu)

Medical Function: relaxes the smooth muscles of bronchi (bronchial smooth muscle relaxation)
used as material for moxibustion (moxa; ai rong/艾絨)
Dosage: 1 ~ 3 qian. Qian = 3.75 grams (traditional) or approximately 4 to 11 grams.
Samples of Formulae:
For heavy menses or bleeding during pregnancy: Ai Ye (Mugwort leaf) with Dang Gui (Angelica sinensis root) 3 qian each, Bai Shao (White peony root) 3 qian, Sheng Di Huang (Rehmannia root) 3 qian, Chuan Xiong (Szechuan lovage rhizome) 1 qian; boil with water and take orally.

For vomiting blood, nose bleeding, blood in stool, bleeding in hemorrhoids: Ai Ye (Mugwort leaf) 3 qian, Sheng Di Huang (Rehmannia root) 3 qian, Bo Ye [Bai Ye/柏葉] (Platycladus/Chinese arborvitae leaf) 3 qian, He Ye (Lotus leaf) 2 qian; boil with water and take orally.

For chronic diarrhea: Ai Ye (Mugwort leaf) 7.5 g, Sheng Jiang (Fresh ginger) 12 g, Chen Pi (Aged tangerine peel) 4 g; boil into a thick extract and take orally while warm.

Use as fuel in moxibustion.

Boil with water to be used as bath water.

For threatened abortion: Gu Shen An Tai Yin (固腎安胎飲).
Contraindications: Use caution in cases of yin deficiency or xue re (heat in blood). The effective ingredient is the volatile oil and it is the toxic ingredient which can cause inflammation of the skin and mucous membranes. Taken orally it can irritate the digestive tract. After absorption it can reach the liver and obstruct hepatic metabolism and can cause jaundice-type hepatitis. Its effect toward the central nervous system is prominent; in toxic reaction the central nervous system becomes overactive and can induce seizure. Due to changes of neural reflexes it can damage blood vessel walls and cause reactive hyperemia of the uterus and bleeding. Oral toxic range: 20 ~ 30 g. [12]
Research: A report from Shanghai Donghua Hospital and others: Using ai ye disinfection incense (made by Shanghai Everyday Chemical Products), which consists of 30% of Cang Zhu (Atractylodes rhizome) powder and 20% of Ai Ye (mugwort leaf) powder, smoking for 4 hours can kill β-Hemolytic streptococcus - A group, Pneumonococcus, Hemophilus influenzae, and Staphylococcus aureus. Smoking for 8 hours can kill Pseudomonas aeruginosa and can inhibit the growth of Bacillus subtilis.
Notes:
Li Shizhen stated: “Ai ye of Qizhou is superior; it is used to fill prescriptions, valued under heaven, and is called Qi Ai (蘄艾).”

Prescription-name processing notes: When written as Ai Ye (艾葉/艾叶) it refers to raw, dry ai ye. Ai Rong (艾絨) is the smashed leaves and branches made into a woolly material for moxa. Cu Ai Ye (醋艾葉) or Cu Ai Rong (醋艾絨) is prepared by mixing clean ai ye or ai rong with rice vinegar, allowing it to be absorbed, then stir-frying over low heat until slightly scorched. Ai Tan (艾炭; also Ai Ye Tan, 艾葉炭) is made by stir-frying clean ai ye over low heat until brown and charred, then removing, spraying with water to extinguish sparks, and drying under the sun.

Moxibustion material note: For moxibustion, stale ai ye more than a year old should be used, because fresh ai ye contains more essential oil, burns faster, and the fumes are harmful.

Maladies Treated: edema from heart or kidney disease
Samples of Formulae: For treatment of edema: Composition: can dou (fava bean) 60 g; dong gua pi (winter melon peel) 60 g. Preparation: Boil with water. Administration: Take orally. Indication: edema.
Contraindications:
Must be thoroughly cooked before eating.
Individuals with favism or a family history of favism (lack of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase) should avoid fava beans.
Those with spleen deficiency should not eat too much.
Research:
Clinical/toxic observations related to favism: A small percentage of people (men and children especially) after ingestion of broad beans or inhalation of its pollen may develop acute hemolytic anemia, with hemoglobinuria, shock, fatigue, dizziness, gastrointestinal disorders, and increased urinary excretion of bile pigment. In more severe cases, pallor, jaundice, vomiting, back pain, and weakness may occur. After eating raw beans, symptoms generally occur 5 to 24 hours later; sometimes stir-fried beans can also cause symptoms. Inhalation of pollen can trigger faster onset.

Proposed cause of favism: A congenital biochemical defect in some individuals—erythrocytes lack glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase—results in very low reduced glutathione. Upon invasion by fava bean cicine, blood cell lysis can occur.

Animal feeding experiment: Mixing cicine from fava bean into food (1%) and feeding to chicks or rats inhibited their natural growth (animal experiment). Some believe other factors in fava beans, in addition to cicine, can also cause similar hemolysis.

Constituents noted in the root and their biological activities: The root contains serotonin–uracil (5-hydroxyuracil), a metabolic antagonist, and 2,6-diaminopurine, which can inhibit lactic acid bacteria; this inhibition can be reversed by adenosine. These substances can cause bone marrow depletion and injure colon and jejunum epithelium of dogs and rats; they are described as carcinogens (animal observations). The role of DAP (2,6-diaminopurine) is not through pentose nucleic acids; it interferes with the basic metabolic functions of adenosine and guanidine.

Geography: China: mainly produced in eastern and southern parts
Maladies Treated: Treats headache from febrile disease, high fever with unconsciousness, rashes, vomiting blood, nosebleed, pediatric convulsions, throat obstruction, and throat swelling.

Purpura and different types of bleeding where heat is high, resulting in blood being forced to move recklessly (horn; internal use). 
 If the subcutaneous purpura or gum bleeding is due to spleen deficiency and the spleen failing to control blood, then water buffalo horn must not be used to stop bleeding.
Skin allergy: grind the horn with water and apply externally to the affected area (horn; external application).
Medical Function: Lowers the penetrating quality (permeability) of capillaries.
Dosage:
Internal consumption by grinding with water: 6–15 g.
In decoction: 30–120 g.
May be made into pill or powder form.
External use: grind with water and apply to affected areas.
Samples of Formulae: Xi Jiao Di Huang Tang (xi jiao [rhinoceros horn] and rehmannia decoction): shui niu jiao (water buffalo horn) can be used instead of xi jiao.
Contraindications:
Adverse reactions reported in a small number of patients include stomach discomfort, abdominal distension (flatulence), diarrhea, nausea, and insomnia.
Not for use during pregnancy.
Not to be used when there is no heat. Not suitable in cases of pixu (spleen deficiency) or for bleeding due to spleen failing to govern the blood (e.g., subcutaneous purpura, gum bleeding from spleen deficiency).
Notes: This animal material is used as a substitute for rhino horn (xi jiao), whose trade is illegal.

Maladies Treated: Vomiting (stopped with jiang ban xia [ginger-processed pinellia])
Cough (ban xia qu used to transform phlegm and stop cough)
Swelling and nodules: external application using sheng ban xia (raw pinellia) to reduce swelling and disperse nodules
Medical Function: Disperses nodules and eliminates focal distension (散結消痞).
Sheng ban xia (raw pinellia): for external use to reduce swelling and disperse nodules; very toxic.
Qing ban xia (alum-processed pinellia): used for transforming phlegm.
Jiang ban xia (ginger- and alum-processed pinellia): effective in stopping vomiting.
Fa ban xia (processed with gan cao and lime water): effective in drying dampness.

Ban xia qu (fermented pinellia mass made from ground fa ban xia with wheat flour): effective in transforming phlegm and in helping digestion; stops cough; taste bitter, neutral; enters Lung, Spleen, and Large Intestine channels.
Dosage:
4.5 to 12 g.
Concentrated extract: 0.5 to 2 g per day.
Adjust the dosage according to syndrome and body condition.
Samples of Formulae:
ban xia bai zhu tian ma tang (半夏白朮天麻湯)
ban xia xie xin tang (半夏瀉心湯)
er chen tang (二陳湯)
chai hu gui zhi tang (柴胡桂枝湯)
liu jun zi tang (六君子湯)
Contraindications:
Do not use in any cough with bleeding due to yinxu or in those with liver diseases [1].
Use caution in cases of heat.
Not compatible with wu tou (aconite).
Raw ban xia (sheng ban xia) is very toxic. See coniine.
Toxic for the liver.
Antidote for poisoning: use sheng jiang (raw ginger) juice, or decoct sheng jiang (raw ginger), lu dou (mung bean), fang feng (siler), and gan cao (licorice) and drink frequently to detoxify.
Notes:
Sheng ban xia processing procedure: soak in clean water until the center shows no white core when cut; remove and drain; slice to about 3 mm thickness; sun-dry or dry over low heat. Raw ban xia is strong and toxic; generally used externally for reducing swelling and dispersing nodules.

Ban xia qu: made by grinding fa ban xia, adding wheat flour, forming into cookie shapes, and fermenting. Its properties are bitter and neutral; it enters the Lung, Spleen, and Large Intestine channels.
